Subject: Re: [junit] Using real data or test data?

My views on testing using real time data...

1. Real time data will help yo=
u understand the type of usage of the
system. Accordingly the test data can=
 be created for the unit test.
2. For the functional tests it would be usef=
ul.
3. For the performance tests also it would be useful if the real time
d=
ata simulates high data volume or some extreme load cases.
4. Getting real =
time data from customers is a difficult task becoz of
security related conc=
erns.  But it is good to test on the customer
data and certify.
5. If you h=
ave multiple customers using different areas of your
product then testing o=
n one such customer's data might give you a
distorted picture.

May be thes=
e are some of the pointers in the decision making..

~JAK

On 4/13/05, haef=
eleuser <haefeleuser@...> wrote:
>  
>  We test various ERP programs,=
 like purchasing demand calculation 
>  (complex business logic).
>  
>  I =
think it is a better approach to use test data which cover the 
>  various =
use cases or boundaries instead of real data. With "test data" 
>  I mean d=
ata which I create in my test program and which I persist in 
>  the databa=
se. After the test finished, I delete the test data (with an 
>  EntityGarb=
ageCollector).
>  
>  But our new project leader thinks we should use only =
real data ("one 
>  dataset for all tests"). I don't think that this would =
work. We need 
>  both strategies I think, even if one solution seems to be=
 redundant.
>  
>  To only use real test data has big disadvantages in my o=
pinion:
>  - if data changes (real data does), then tests break
>  - you ne=
ed much more real data than test data to cover all the 
>  boundaries and u=
se cases
>  - if you add real data or remove real data from the dataset, te=
sts 
>  might break
>  
>  What do you think about it?
>  
>  
>
